text: There are two requirements travel companies should meet to qualify as genuine eco-tourism.
First, tourist main motivation should be to appreciate and observe the natural world without interfering.
And second, the money they spend should support traditional communities.
Clearly, having your photograph taken with a chained and drugged tiger does not meet these requirements.
But not all companies claiming to be eco-tourism behaves so irresponsibly.

According to Antonio Bollingbrook Kent, who runs small-scale wildlife expeditions to some of the most remote places on earth, it's possible to put travel companies on a sliding scale from good to bad.
On BBC Radio 4's programme Costing the Earth, Antonio discussed her work in Tajikistan, a country where eco-tourism is making a positive impact on both animal and human communities.
The other end of the scale is Tajikistan, where I work a lot, which gets less than two dozen wildlife tourists a year.

Antonio uses the phrase, at the other end of the scale, as a way of contrasting irresponsible tourist companies with what's happening in Tajikistan.
There, animals including snow leopards and mountain ungulates are being protected by eco-tourist projects run by non-governmental organisations or NGOs.
Organisations trying to achieve environmental or social aims outside of government control.
These NGOs are grassroots organisations, meaning that they are run from the bottom up by ordinary people rather than leaders.
Despite getting very few eco-tourists a year, the money they spend in Tajikistan goes a long way.
